replies.msg:
呢封係佢覆我嘅email,粗字係重點

Thank-you for your email expressing your concerns about the Hong Kong Fugitives Offenders Ordinance. I am very sorry that I did not get back to you before events escalated.

In response to your message, I agree with your analysis of the situation in Hong Kong. The Extradition Law undermines the Sino-British Joint declaration. Furthermore, given that mainland China cannot be trusted to dispense justice in a fair and transparent manner, the proposed legislation threatens both the security of Hong Kongers and the interests of British businesses.

Since you sent your email the protesters have made some progress, resulting in the indefinite suspension of the ordinance. However, I believe that there is still work to be done. Specifically, the Chief Executive needs to scrap the Extradition Law entirely and there needs to be an independent investigation into police violence against earlier peaceful protests.

The Liberal Democrats are firm on Britain's interests and responsibilities to Hong Kong. After using the urgent question to the House of Commons to urge the PM to take firmer action, Alastair Carmichael, the Chief Whip stated that "“The Conservative government has a duty to ensure that there is an independent investigation into the police violence of 12^th June, as well as secure the absolute withdrawal of the dangerous Extradition Bill once and for all.
“We made a promise to the people of Hong Kong in 1997. Whoever the next Prime Minister is must honour that and protect democracy and the rule of law in Hong Kong.” If the situation in Hong Kong takes a turn for the worse, we will continue to press the government to act.

*In fact, I have a personal interest in the events in Hong Kong because my political hero, Paddy Ashdown, led a campaign to guarantee full British citizenship to BNO passport holders. I think that we should resurrect this idea and show to China that we mean business.*

I can assure you that I share your concerns about the rule of law in Hong Kong and I think that it is important that we stand up for our values in the region at this critical time.

Yours sincerely,

Ed Davey

Rt Hon Sir Edward Davey MP
Kingston and Surbiton (Liberal Democrat)

呢封係佢覆我嘅email,粗字係重點

Thank-you for your email expressing your concerns about the Hong Kong Fugitives Offenders Ordinance. I am very sorry that I did not get back to you before events escalated.

In response to your message, I agree with your analysis of the situation in Hong Kong. The Extradition Law undermines the Sino-British Joint declaration. Furthermore, given that mainland China cannot be trusted to dispense justice in a fair and transparent manner, the proposed legislation threatens both the security of Hong Kongers and the interests of British businesses.

Since you sent your email the protesters have made some progress, resulting in the indefinite suspension of the ordinance. However, I believe that there is still work to be done. Specifically, the Chief Executive needs to scrap the Extradition Law entirely and there needs to be an independent investigation into police violence against earlier peaceful protests.

The Liberal Democrats are firm on Britain's interests and responsibilities to Hong Kong. After using the urgent question to the House of Commons to urge the PM to take firmer action, Alastair Carmichael, the Chief Whip stated that "“The Conservative government has a duty to ensure that there is an independent investigation into the police violence of 12^th June, as well as secure the absolute withdrawal of the dangerous Extradition Bill once and for all.
“We made a promise to the people of Hong Kong in 1997. Whoever the next Prime Minister is must honour that and protect democracy and the rule of law in Hong Kong.” If the situation in Hong Kong takes a turn for the worse, we will continue to press the government to act.

*In fact, I have a personal interest in the events in Hong Kong because my political hero, Paddy Ashdown, led a campaign to guarantee full British citizenship to BNO passport holders. I think that we should resurrect this idea and show to China that we mean business.*

I can assure you that I share your concerns about the rule of law in Hong Kong and I think that it is important that we stand up for our values in the region at this critical time.

Yours sincerely,

Ed Davey

Rt Hon Sir Edward Davey MP
Kingston and Surbiton (Liberal Democrat)

其實應該分幾個phrase做
1. 原BNO持有人 （一直有續期，應該得十幾廿萬左右）
2. BNO持有人 （冇續期)
3. BNO繼承人 （即父母持BNO, 或兄弟姊妹差幾年出世，證明到血緣關系）
4. 97前香港出世/ 香港定居，有香港出世紙，但全家冇BNO
5. 97後香港出世，全家冇BNO，但證明到父母其中一方97前已經定居香港或於香港出世（呢個應該cover到00後）


但全部都應該要做一次政治審查先，冇理由港豬藍絲與狗都有份。佢地去到只會令英國沉倫，又影衰我地搞到同當地人產生衝突，好似自由行同新移民咁。

quote.msg:
其實應該分幾個phrase做
1. 原BNO持有人 （一直有續期，應該得十幾廿萬左右）
2. BNO持有人 （冇續期)
3. BNO繼承人 （即父母持BNO, 或兄弟姊妹差幾年出世，證明到血緣關系）
4. 97前香港出世/ 香港定居，有香港出世紙，但全家冇BNO
5. 97後香港出世，全家冇BNO，但證明到父母其中一方97前已經定居香港或於香港出世（呢個應該cover到00後）


但全部都應該要做一次政治審查先，冇理由港豬藍絲與狗都有份。佢地去到只會令英國沉倫，又影衰我地搞到同當地人產生衝突，好似自由行同新移民咁。

quote.msg:
呢封係佢覆我嘅email,粗字係重點

Thank-you for your email expressing your concerns about the Hong Kong Fugitives Offenders Ordinance. I am very sorry that I did not get back to you before events escalated.

In response to your message, I agree with your analysis of the situation in Hong Kong. The Extradition Law undermines the Sino-British Joint declaration. Furthermore, given that mainland China cannot be trusted to dispense justice in a fair and transparent manner, the proposed legislation threatens both the security of Hong Kongers and the interests of British businesses.

Since you sent your email the protesters have made some progress, resulting in the indefinite suspension of the ordinance. However, I believe that there is still work to be done. Specifically, the Chief Executive needs to scrap the Extradition Law entirely and there needs to be an independent investigation into police violence against earlier peaceful protests.

The Liberal Democrats are firm on Britain's interests and responsibilities to Hong Kong. After using the urgent question to the House of Commons to urge the PM to take firmer action, Alastair Carmichael, the Chief Whip stated that "“The Conservative government has a duty to ensure that there is an independent investigation into the police violence of 12^th June, as well as secure the absolute withdrawal of the dangerous Extradition Bill once and for all.
“We made a promise to the people of Hong Kong in 1997. Whoever the next Prime Minister is must honour that and protect democracy and the rule of law in Hong Kong.” If the situation in Hong Kong takes a turn for the worse, we will continue to press the government to act.

*In fact, I have a personal interest in the events in Hong Kong because my political hero, Paddy Ashdown, led a campaign to guarantee full British citizenship to BNO passport holders. I think that we should resurrect this idea and show to China that we mean business.*

I can assure you that I share your concerns about the rule of law in Hong Kong and I think that it is important that we stand up for our values in the region at this critical time.

Yours sincerely,

Ed Davey

Rt Hon Sir Edward Davey MP
Kingston and Surbiton (Liberal Democrat)

30. 我不清楚我是否有過BN(O)身份，有方法查詢?
可以使用「身分證大法」得知你是否BN(O):

合符以下條件基本上可以肯定你有過BNO身份：
- 1997年7月1日前未滿11歲
- 身份證首次簽發日期為(06-97)或之前
- 香港出世而且出世紙寫有'Established'

中晒三樣係肯定有過BNO，冇可能中晒冇BNO
全中以上三項條件代表你父母曾經在主權移交前代你申請過BNO
不符合以上全部條件並不代表你沒有過BNO身份

當年拎BDTC 係唔駛攞香港身份證
同埋97前同樣係強制11歲以上人士攞香港身份證

所以個條件應該係
1/7/97前未夠11歲，身份證(07-97)前發出，同出世紙寫Established

quote.msg:
呢封係佢覆我嘅email,粗字係重點

Thank-you for your email expressing your concerns about the Hong Kong Fugitives Offenders Ordinance. I am very sorry that I did not get back to you before events escalated.

In response to your message, I agree with your analysis of the situation in Hong Kong. The Extradition Law undermines the Sino-British Joint declaration. Furthermore, given that mainland China cannot be trusted to dispense justice in a fair and transparent manner, the proposed legislation threatens both the security of Hong Kongers and the interests of British businesses.

Since you sent your email the protesters have made some progress, resulting in the indefinite suspension of the ordinance. However, I believe that there is still work to be done. Specifically, the Chief Executive needs to scrap the Extradition Law entirely and there needs to be an independent investigation into police violence against earlier peaceful protests.

The Liberal Democrats are firm on Britain's interests and responsibilities to Hong Kong. After using the urgent question to the House of Commons to urge the PM to take firmer action, Alastair Carmichael, the Chief Whip stated that "“The Conservative government has a duty to ensure that there is an independent investigation into the police violence of 12^th June, as well as secure the absolute withdrawal of the dangerous Extradition Bill once and for all.
“We made a promise to the people of Hong Kong in 1997. Whoever the next Prime Minister is must honour that and protect democracy and the rule of law in Hong Kong.” If the situation in Hong Kong takes a turn for the worse, we will continue to press the government to act.

*In fact, I have a personal interest in the events in Hong Kong because my political hero, Paddy Ashdown, led a campaign to guarantee full British citizenship to BNO passport holders. I think that we should resurrect this idea and show to China that we mean business.*

I can assure you that I share your concerns about the rule of law in Hong Kong and I think that it is important that we stand up for our values in the region at this critical time.

Yours sincerely,

Ed Davey

Rt Hon Sir Edward Davey MP
Kingston and Surbiton (Liberal Democrat)

1. 原BNO持有人 （一直有續期，應該得十幾廿萬左右）

4. 97前香港出世/ 香港定居，有香港出世紙，但全家冇BNO
5. 97後香港出世，全家冇BNO，但證明到父母其中一方97前已經定居香港或於香港出世（呢個應該cover到00後）

呢封係佢覆我嘅email,粗字係重點

Thank-you for your email expressing your concerns about the Hong Kong Fugitives Offenders Ordinance. I am very sorry that I did not get back to you before events escalated.

In response to your message, I agree with your analysis of the situation in Hong Kong. The Extradition Law undermines the Sino-British Joint declaration. Furthermore, given that mainland China cannot be trusted to dispense justice in a fair and transparent manner, the proposed legislation threatens both the security of Hong Kongers and the interests of British businesses.

Since you sent your email the protesters have made some progress, resulting in the indefinite suspension of the ordinance. However, I believe that there is still work to be done. Specifically, the Chief Executive needs to scrap the Extradition Law entirely and there needs to be an independent investigation into police violence against earlier peaceful protests.

The Liberal Democrats are firm on Britain's interests and responsibilities to Hong Kong. After using the urgent question to the House of Commons to urge the PM to take firmer action, Alastair Carmichael, the Chief Whip stated that "“The Conservative government has a duty to ensure that there is an independent investigation into the police violence of 12^th June, as well as secure the absolute withdrawal of the dangerous Extradition Bill once and for all.
“We made a promise to the people of Hong Kong in 1997. Whoever the next Prime Minister is must honour that and protect democracy and the rule of law in Hong Kong.” If the situation in Hong Kong takes a turn for the worse, we will continue to press the government to act.

*In fact, I have a personal interest in the events in Hong Kong because my political hero, Paddy Ashdown, led a campaign to guarantee full British citizenship to BNO passport holders. I think that we should resurrect this idea and show to China that we mean business.*

I can assure you that I share your concerns about the rule of law in Hong Kong and I think that it is important that we stand up for our values in the region at this critical time.

Yours sincerely,

Ed Davey

Rt Hon Sir Edward Davey MP
Kingston and Surbiton (Liberal Democrat)

I am writing as a constituent of yours of Hong Kong heritage to bring your attention as my Member of Parliament to a currently proposed change to the Fugitives Offenders Ordinance (often referred to as Extradition Law) of Hong Kong. This bill, if passed, will pose an imminent threat to civil rights in the former British territory and have serious effects on British interests there, because of its erasure of the judicial boundary between Hong Kong and Mainland China. The European Union has lodged a formal diplomatic summon with the Hong Kong government over this matter [1], and the United Kingdom and Canada have also issued a statement [2]. However, I am afraid that these statements were mere lip service, and stronger action from Parliament will be necessary.

[1]  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-extradition-eu/eu-lodges-formal-diplomatic-note-against-contentious-hong-kong-extradition-bill-idUSKCN1SU0OS?fbclid=IwAR1ZAfU92VsZOS5VbTbmZZLa90prascHA7DXnbr0Fji099GSmy-AdNiAAzI  
[2]  https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-and-canada-joint-statement-on-hong-kong?fbclid=IwAR0FCYHK3EmmOWugtxVwJBhe3eyR2NANKzlpYv4fSv2jFl0K1WdC8X25PUk  

The Hong Kong government currently has extradition agreements with 18 countries, including the UK. The proposed amendment will extend extradition coverage to laws of Mainland China which has a track record of arbitrary enforcement and interpretation of the law. Once enacted, the ordinance threatens all people regardless of their nationality. For example, activists, political dissidents and even foreign tourists or travellers could be subject to arrest and be detained while they are in transit, travelling, working and living in Hong Kong. This will pose a serious threat to British interests in Hong Kong, especially to international corporations and NGOs that have conducted sensitive work that may be subject to arbitrary interpretation of laws in China.

Until now, the judicial separation between Hong Kong and Mainland China, and the strong track record of free speech and the rule of law, has allowed international organisations and British businesses to thrive in Hong Kong and use the city as a base camp for their East Asian operations. Although the Hong Kong government has claimed that ‘political criminals’ will not be extradited, in the case of the imprisonment and prosecution of the Causeway Bay booksellers in Mainland China, the booksellers have been charged by the Mainland Chinese government with criminal offences like traffic offences, illegal business operations, libel, fraud or extortion. These amendments would advance the Mainland Chinese government’s suppression of dissent as well as deprive Hong Kong citizens and foreign nationals in Hong Kong of their legal protection.

There are an estimated 200,000 British citizens in Hong Kong, and a further 3 million there who hold British National (Overseas) status; and there are also an estimated 100,000 Hongkongers in the UK. This law may seem to be a local law in Hong Kong, but would in effect threaten the very existence of British business and cultural connections to East Asia.

I urge you, as my Member of Parliament, to request our Parliament and Government to take further action to oppose the introduction of this proposed extradition law in Hong Kong, in order to secure British interests and fulfil the UK's duty to "high degree of autonomy" and the rights and freedoms in Hong Kong set down in the Sino-British Joint Declaration.

Yours sincerely,

Press Release: Steve Double MP presented a petition to the House of Commons on the rights of British National Overseas passport holders on Wednesday 10th of July 2019.

The petition urges the United Kingdom Government to carry out an urgent review of the rights of British National (Overseas) passport holders, including the rights of Abode; addressing the need for these passport holders in Hong Kong for British consular assistance in view of the ongoing political situation in Hong Kong.

Steve Double MP spoke in the House of Commons. Parliament TV link: https://parliamentlive.tv/event/index/883d54e3-57bf-4a92-9f18-eba92a40a193?in=18:12:01&out=18:13:22

Mr Double said: “I rise to present a petition on behalf of a group of over 3000 British National Overseas Passport Holders living in Hong Kong and the UK. These British nationals still feel proud of their historic ties with the UK and share our values.

In view of the deteriorating state of human rights and democracy in Hong Kong, the petitions therefore request that the House of Commons urges the Government to carry out an urgent review of the rights of British National (Overseas) passport holders, addressing the need for these passport holders in Hong Kong and China to access British consular assistance and request diplomatic protection in view of the ongoing political situation in Hong Kong, and allowing BN(O) passport holders with Tiers 4 and 5 visas to be given routes to residency in the UK."

Petition details as below:
Petition Title: Rights of British National (Overseas) Passport Holders

To the House of Commons,

Declares that the rights of British National (Overseas) passport holders should be reviewed; notes that over 150,000 BN(O) passport holders in Hong Kong and China are unable to access British consular assistance and request diplomatic protection despite the deteriorating state of human rights and rule of law in Hong Kong; further that citizens of British Hong Kong were issued the BN(O) passport without the right of abode in the UK as a political compromise with the Chinese government prior to the 1997 handover, instead of being given British citizenship as is the case for citizens of other former British colonies; further that these British nationals still feel proud of their ties with the UK and share British values; further that many highly educated and skilled BN(O) passport holders studying and working in the UK under Tiers 4 and 5 visas are unable to remain and contribute the UK economy and society; and further that a petition on behalf of a group of 240 BNO passport holders and their families have received over 3000 signatures.

The petitioners therefore request that the House of Commons urges the Government to carry out an urgent review of the rights of British National (Overseas) passport holders, addressing the need for these passport holders in Hong Kong and China to be access British consular assistance and request diplomatic protection in view of the ongoing political situation in Hong Kong, and allowing BN(O) passport holders with Tiers 4 and 5 visas to be given routes to residency in the UK.

【佔中前生？】英解密檔案揭　李光耀曾提議港政要　20萬人集體威脅移民　阻京干預
立場報道2018/12/28 — 12:27

英國國家檔案館最新一批解密檔案顯示，已故新加坡前總理李光耀在六四事件後，曾與時任英國首相戴卓爾夫人分析香港局勢，李光耀曾建議香港約20萬真正有影響力的人，組織起來以集體移民來威脅北京，阻止北京干預香港。

六四後與戴卓爾會面紀錄

《明報》和《香港01》報道，今次公開的是兩人會面後，英國首相府的會面紀錄，李光耀和戴卓爾夫人，是在1989年10月到馬來西亞出席英聯邦國家首腦會議期間，距離六四屠殺僅四個月；李光耀在會面中形容事件是「悲劇（tragedy）」，令鄧小平花十年建立的班底毀於一旦，舊勢力重新抬頭，這結果對中國是災難性，他又認為若鄧小平能親身處理和更有警覺性，趙紫陽在權鬥方面不是這麼差，事情完全可以避免。

為香港感到惋惜

李光耀隨後講到香港的情況，表示「為香港感到惋惜（felt very sorry for Hong Kong）」，因為1997件主權移交後，北京可以為所欲為，特別是涉及到權力鬥爭，中國根本不在乎國際形象。

倡非對抗方式迫中國聆聽

李光耀透露，曾在吉隆波和香港行政立法兩會代表團會面，李光耀建議他們不要和中國「鬥爭（fight）」，而是「陳情或討價還價（plead or bargain）」，同時組織起來，令自己「有潛力破壞中國利益（could do potential damage to China's interest）」，這種非對抗方式（non-confrontational approach）可以有效迫中國聆聽意見。

集體威脅移民　外國政府配合撤移民監

李光耀建議約20萬在香港真正有影響力（really mattered）的人，威脅離開香港拖跨香港管治和經濟，阻止北京干預香港，其他政府亦應該配合，提供居留權予這20萬人，但取消他們的「移民監」，若香港一切正常他們會留在香港，有必要就隨時可以離開。

勝出港民主唯有「愛港恨中」

而對香港民主進程，他認為在這問題上挑戰中國是大錯特錯（great mistake），如果當時就落實全面民主選舉，中國只會派幹部（candres）治港，造成社會衝突，鄧小平指治港的人要愛國愛港，但他認為要勝出香港民主選舉的唯一方法是「愛香港、恨中國（love Hong Kong and hate China）」，不過檔案未有進一步解釋這個觀點。

2015年逝世的李光耀，在新加坡國內反共立場鮮明，令他在文革期間成為中國官媒狠批的對象，指他是「帝國主義者的傀儡」、「美帝馴服的走狗」等；但到70年代中新關係緩和，1980年《人民日報》以頭版報道李光耀訪華，他第一次被稱為「中國人民的老朋友」，之後李光耀和歷任北京領導人關係密切，今年慶祝改革盟開放40週年大會，已故的李光耀獲頒中國改革友誼獎章。

quote.msg:
呢封係佢覆我嘅email,粗字係重點

Thank-you for your email expressing your concerns about the Hong Kong Fugitives Offenders Ordinance. I am very sorry that I did not get back to you before events escalated.

In response to your message, I agree with your analysis of the situation in Hong Kong. The Extradition Law undermines the Sino-British Joint declaration. Furthermore, given that mainland China cannot be trusted to dispense justice in a fair and transparent manner, the proposed legislation threatens both the security of Hong Kongers and the interests of British businesses.

Since you sent your email the protesters have made some progress, resulting in the indefinite suspension of the ordinance. However, I believe that there is still work to be done. Specifically, the Chief Executive needs to scrap the Extradition Law entirely and there needs to be an independent investigation into police violence against earlier peaceful protests.

The Liberal Democrats are firm on Britain's interests and responsibilities to Hong Kong. After using the urgent question to the House of Commons to urge the PM to take firmer action, Alastair Carmichael, the Chief Whip stated that "“The Conservative government has a duty to ensure that there is an independent investigation into the police violence of 12^th June, as well as secure the absolute withdrawal of the dangerous Extradition Bill once and for all.
“We made a promise to the people of Hong Kong in 1997. Whoever the next Prime Minister is must honour that and protect democracy and the rule of law in Hong Kong.” If the situation in Hong Kong takes a turn for the worse, we will continue to press the government to act.

*In fact, I have a personal interest in the events in Hong Kong because my political hero, Paddy Ashdown, led a campaign to guarantee full British citizenship to BNO passport holders. I think that we should resurrect this idea and show to China that we mean business.*

I can assure you that I share your concerns about the rule of law in Hong Kong and I think that it is important that we stand up for our values in the region at this critical time.

Yours sincerely,

Ed Davey

Rt Hon Sir Edward Davey MP
Kingston and Surbiton (Liberal Democrat)

Petition details as below:
Petition Title: Rights of British National (Overseas) Passport Holders

To the House of Commons,

Declares that the rights of British National (Overseas) passport holders should be reviewed; notes that over 150,000 BN(O) passport holders in Hong Kong and China are unable to access British consular assistance and request diplomatic protection despite the deteriorating state of human rights and rule of law in Hong Kong; further that citizens of British Hong Kong were issued the BN(O) passport without the right of abode in the UK as a political compromise with the Chinese government prior to the 1997 handover, instead of being given British citizenship as is the case for citizens of other former British colonies; further that these British nationals still feel proud of their ties with the UK and share British values; further that many highly educated and skilled BN(O) passport holders studying and working in the UK under Tiers 4 and 5 visas are unable to remain and contribute the UK economy and society; and further that a petition on behalf of a group of 240 BNO passport holders and their families have received over 3000 signatures.

The petitioners therefore request that the House of Commons urges the Government to carry out an urgent review of the rights of British National (Overseas) passport holders, addressing the need for these passport holders in Hong Kong and China to be access British consular assistance and request diplomatic protection in view of the ongoing political situation in Hong Kong, and allowing BN(O) passport holders with Tiers 4 and 5 visas to be given routes to residency in the UK.

Declares that the rights of British National (Overseas) passport holders should be reviewed; notes that over 150,000 BN(O) passport holders in Hong Kong and China are unable to access British consular assistance and request diplomatic protection despite the deteriorating state of human rights and rule of law in Hong Kong; further that citizens of British Hong Kong were issued the BN(O) passport without the right of abode in the UK as a political compromise with the Chinese government prior to the 1997 handover, instead of being given British citizenship as is the case for citizens of other former British colonies; further that these British nationals still feel proud of their ties with the UK and share British values; further that many highly educated and skilled BN(O) passport holders studying and working in the UK under Tiers 4 and 5 visas are unable to remain and contribute the UK economy and society; and further that a petition on behalf of a group of 240 BNO passport holders and their families have received over 3000 signatures.

The petitioners therefore request that the House of Commons urges the Government to carry out an urgent review of the rights of British National (Overseas) passport holders, addressing the need for these passport holders in Hong Kong and China to be access British consular assistance and request diplomatic protection in view of the ongoing political situation in Hong Kong, and allowing BN(O) passport holders with Tiers 4 and 5 visas to be given routes to residency in the UK.

I am writing as a constituent of yours of Hong Kong heritage to bring your attention as my Member of Parliament to a currently proposed change to the Fugitives Offenders Ordinance (often referred to as Extradition Law) of Hong Kong. This bill, if passed, will pose an imminent threat to civil rights in the former British territory and have serious effects on British interests there, because of its erasure of the judicial boundary between Hong Kong and Mainland China. The European Union has lodged a formal diplomatic summon with the Hong Kong government over this matter [1], and the United Kingdom and Canada have also issued a statement [2]. However, I am afraid that these statements were mere lip service, and stronger action from Parliament will be necessary.

[1]  https://www.reuters.com/article/us-hongkong-extradition-eu/eu-lodges-formal-diplomatic-note-against-contentious-hong-kong-extradition-bill-idUSKCN1SU0OS?fbclid=IwAR1ZAfU92VsZOS5VbTbmZZLa90prascHA7DXnbr0Fji099GSmy-AdNiAAzI  
[2]  https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-and-canada-joint-statement-on-hong-kong?fbclid=IwAR0FCYHK3EmmOWugtxVwJBhe3eyR2NANKzlpYv4fSv2jFl0K1WdC8X25PUk  

The Hong Kong government currently has extradition agreements with 18 countries, including the UK. The proposed amendment will extend extradition coverage to laws of Mainland China which has a track record of arbitrary enforcement and interpretation of the law. Once enacted, the ordinance threatens all people regardless of their nationality. For example, activists, political dissidents and even foreign tourists or travellers could be subject to arrest and be detained while they are in transit, travelling, working and living in Hong Kong. This will pose a serious threat to British interests in Hong Kong, especially to international corporations and NGOs that have conducted sensitive work that may be subject to arbitrary interpretation of laws in China.

Until now, the judicial separation between Hong Kong and Mainland China, and the strong track record of free speech and the rule of law, has allowed international organisations and British businesses to thrive in Hong Kong and use the city as a base camp for their East Asian operations. Although the Hong Kong government has claimed that ‘political criminals’ will not be extradited, in the case of the imprisonment and prosecution of the Causeway Bay booksellers in Mainland China, the booksellers have been charged by the Mainland Chinese government with criminal offences like traffic offences, illegal business operations, libel, fraud or extortion. These amendments would advance the Mainland Chinese government’s suppression of dissent as well as deprive Hong Kong citizens and foreign nationals in Hong Kong of their legal protection.

There are an estimated 200,000 British citizens in Hong Kong, and a further 3 million there who hold British National (Overseas) status; and there are also an estimated 100,000 Hongkongers in the UK. This law may seem to be a local law in Hong Kong, but would in effect threaten the very existence of British business and cultural connections to East Asia.

I urge you, as my Member of Parliament, to request our Parliament and Government to take further action to oppose the introduction of this proposed extradition law in Hong Kong, in order to secure British interests and fulfil the UK's duty to "high degree of autonomy" and the rights and freedoms in Hong Kong set down in the Sino-British Joint Declaration.

Yours sincerely,

replies.msg:
其實繼承權問題又有兩浸，唔係睇落咁易

殖民時代，公務員既bc 以而家既用字即係British national by descent，其後代係要喺英國屬地出世先可以繼承到bc（有三個exceptions，包括係當兵而註外地，或者其他為英政府服務既原因而去左外地）

換言之點解有一班97 前出世既年輕人有bc 就係因為當時佢地既父母係公務員，而佢地喺香港呢個英屬地出世所以可以繼承到國藉

咁問題就黎
1. 如果bno 平權成同當時公務員一樣係British national by descent，咁其實97 71 後喺香港出世既BNO holders 後代都係繼承唔到，因為97 71 後香港已經唔再係英國屬地

2. 如果為左解決問題1 而將BNO holders 平權為British national otherwise by descent （後代毋須於英國屬地出世都可以繼承國藉既一種英國國藉），喺政策上會唔會圍背左當時既公務員權利呢？而且咁做個劃線問題會唔會更大？

quote.msg:
呢封係佢覆我嘅email,粗字係重點

Thank-you for your email expressing your concerns about the Hong Kong Fugitives Offenders Ordinance. I am very sorry that I did not get back to you before events escalated.

In response to your message, I agree with your analysis of the situation in Hong Kong. The Extradition Law undermines the Sino-British Joint declaration. Furthermore, given that mainland China cannot be trusted to dispense justice in a fair and transparent manner, the proposed legislation threatens both the security of Hong Kongers and the interests of British businesses.

Since you sent your email the protesters have made some progress, resulting in the indefinite suspension of the ordinance. However, I believe that there is still work to be done. Specifically, the Chief Executive needs to scrap the Extradition Law entirely and there needs to be an independent investigation into police violence against earlier peaceful protests.

The Liberal Democrats are firm on Britain's interests and responsibilities to Hong Kong. After using the urgent question to the House of Commons to urge the PM to take firmer action, Alastair Carmichael, the Chief Whip stated that "“The Conservative government has a duty to ensure that there is an independent investigation into the police violence of 12^th June, as well as secure the absolute withdrawal of the dangerous Extradition Bill once and for all.
“We made a promise to the people of Hong Kong in 1997. Whoever the next Prime Minister is must honour that and protect democracy and the rule of law in Hong Kong.” If the situation in Hong Kong takes a turn for the worse, we will continue to press the government to act.

*In fact, I have a personal interest in the events in Hong Kong because my political hero, Paddy Ashdown, led a campaign to guarantee full British citizenship to BNO passport holders. I think that we should resurrect this idea and show to China that we mean business.*

I can assure you that I share your concerns about the rule of law in Hong Kong and I think that it is important that we stand up for our values in the region at this critical time.

Yours sincerely,

Ed Davey

Rt Hon Sir Edward Davey MP
